Award.AwardTitle: ACS Symposium on Antimicrobial and Cell-Penetrating Polymers
Award.AbstractNarration:
This symposium will provide a platform for the dissemination of the current results in the field and will serve as a broad interdisciplinary forum for discussions on the current challenges and opportunities for polymer chemists, biophysicists, and microbiologists. The key contributions will delineate the complex interplay between chemical structure, biophysical properties, and biological activity of synthetic polymers that are designed to mimic the salient features of host defense peptides. Optimization of polymer structures to enhance antibacterial potency and reduce toxicity to human cells will be a key focus area. Additionally, discussions on the mechanisms of action exerted by these synthetic macromolecules will further facilitate their potential future use in a clinical setting. The event is likely to evoke keen interest to researchers who specialize in polymer science and engineering, biophysics, microbiology and biomaterials.

This symposium will facilitate establishing collaborative efforts between experimental and computational researchers, as well as bridging the gap between polymer chemists and people in the biophysical sciences. Showcasing the advances of interdisciplinary investigators while training young scientists of the next generation is also a central theme as it provides focusing for new research avenues and fostering the development of the next generation of investigators. Significant are made to enhance the participation of groups underrepresented in science and engineering. The list of confirmed speakers includes 14 female scientists, 3 minorities, and 11 junior researchers (Postdoctoral Researchers and Assistant Professors). Presentations by graduate students and post-doctoral researchers, including members of underrepresented groups, will be strongly encouraged through active advertisement and support for travel expenses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Antibiotic drugs are an indispensible part of everyday medical care in the modern world. Unfortunately, many harmful types of bacterial infections are now "resistant" to older drugs such as penicillin and even recent drugs like ciprofloxacin and methicillin. Innovative new strategies are urgently needed to combat this worrisome trend, which the World Health Organization (WHO) has labeled as "Bad Bugs, No Drugs". 

This NSF grant was used to support a science and engineering symposium on the topic of antibacterial polymer materials that can kill harmful bacteria on contact, thus stopping their spread in the community. The two-day event was held as part of the American Chemical Society (ACS) National Meeting in Orlando, FL, in the Spring of 2019. The conference featured oral presentations by a diverse array of expert speakers from industry and university research laboratories. New and emerging technologies were discussed in great detail. Each of the 30+ lectures were very well attended by members of the ACS and the broader community ,with standing room only for most fo the two days. In addition to the talks, there was a great deal of discussions and interactions between different scientistics from various technical backgrounds. Such "cross-pollination" of ideas is expected to invigorate and accelerate this important field of research. We expect that the concepts and strategies discussed during this meeting will lead to new technologies for antibacterial products, paints, surface coatings, biomedical implant devices, and perhaps even new drugs that are not prone to induce antibacterial resistance. Ultimately, the continued support of the NSF in this critical area of science and engineering will help to make the country and the world a safer place in the future.
